abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and project sustainability is rated, likely.
            Overall Borrower performance is satisfactory: Despite some
            problems noted in the report, the Ministry of Public Finance
            (MPG) in particular, maintained a strong interest in the
            progress of the report, assisted in resolving many of the
            financial issues that arose during implementation. The
            Ministry of Education and Research (MER), legally designated
            as the implementation agency, despite two changes in
            Government as part of the regular election schedule in 1996
            and 2000, and three changes in ministers of education,
            remained actively engaged in resolving issues raised by
            supervision missions. World Bank performance, overall, was
            satisfactory: From sector work to supervision, the Bank
            provided adequate teams with a range of expertise in higher
            education reform issues. The dialogue with the Government
            and project agency team was a productive one, acknowledging
            areas of initial policy disagreement and working through the
            analysis to reach agreement, as incorporated into the letter
            of sector development policy of the Government and the
            Policy Matrix of the Project. Other lessons to be
            highlighted include the following: 1) The extensive sector
            work with significant involvement of the local academic
            community, the MER and the MPF, provides a positive lesson
            on the role of sector work in analysis and identification of
            sector issues. This could not have been done without a PHRD
            grant. This also helps to address the political risks
            inherent in the reform process and to build up enough
            support in the face of some opposing constituencies. Second,
            the policy matrix proved important for providing support for
            long-term reform measures by ensuring that the progress on
            policy issues and actions were discussed regularly during
            supervision missions and difficulties and problems in taking
            policy actions could be explored. A unique feature of this
            project compared to most higher education competitive funds
            was the involvement of supervision missions in ex-ante
            reviews of the criteria and procedures as applied in the
            competitions by the councils. The purpose was to review a
            sample of accepted and rejected grant proposals, and to see
            how the councils applied the criteria and procedures. This
            ex-ante review of the grants award process increased project
            sustainability. Fourth, early agreement on allocation of 50
            percent of the grants to new, priority areas proved to be
            highly beneficial since more traditional areas were more
            powerful and would have been the winners of all the grants.
            Fifth, the special round of competition targeted at young
            researchers proved successful ans has been incorporated in
            the research grants competitions run by the Multi-User
            research Center (MURC) out of the government's budget.
            Sixth, seed grants and major grants were beneficial since
            they provided the chance to try out new ideas in pilot
            stages and develop these ideas into major projects.
